UI_visible_response: "Under the Dome" is a work of very broad, very black social satire, indicating its deep engagement with societal issues through a satirical lens1. It is also described as a thriller that explores how individuals and communities respond to an unprecedented crisis, serving as a microcosm of society5. Additionally, it has been noted for its fast-paced, disturbing narrative that incorporates everyday elements to evoke fear10. The story revolves around a small town that is suddenly sealed off from the rest of the world by an enormous transparent dome, which is central to both the novel and its television adaptation7.
traffic_visible_response: "Under the Dome" is a work of very broad, very black social satire, indicating its deep engagement with societal issues through a satirical lens [[1]]. It is also described as a thriller that explores how individuals and communities respond to an unprecedented crisis, serving as a microcosm of society [[5]]. Additionally, it has been noted for its fast-paced, disturbing narrative that incorporates everyday elements to evoke fear [[10]]. The story revolves around a small town that is suddenly sealed off from the rest of the world by an enormous transparent dome, which is central to both the novel and its television adaptation [[7]].
